image:image.image:title: sacrifice

(I love them) This one, with a goat sacrifice and early Stone Age people praying to heathen deities/spirits rocked my world. And so it makes a perfect final image. Enjoy, and conduct the proper rites.

image:image.image:title: Alps
image:image.image:caption: Splendid cross-section of the stratigraphy of the Alps around Lausanne. I gazed at this for quite a few minutes, trying to figure out what was where in the landscape I'd seen and how old, how deformed, etc.

image:image.image:title: tracks

image:image.image:title: barbets
image:image.image:caption: Asian barbet faces: this was fascinating. Kingdon used the paintings to explain how barbet faces vary across species as recognition devices to aid in territorial defense, especially of their nest-holes in trees, in which they face outwards to display their coloured faces. The middle image shows one lone species that has no such territorial competitors and has evolved back into brown colour, perhaps due to relaxed selective pressure for colour. Neat!

image:image.image:title: vulture
image:image.image:caption: Oh my, this took my breath away! Mixed media depicting the varied forms of facial ornaments in vultures; soft tissues used in communcation. And here mounted on a butcher's rack. Do vulture bits mimic their grisly food?

image:image.image:title: sengis
image:image.image:caption: More sengis (elephant shrews); with a note explaining that they are not rodents/insectivores but afrotheres, cousins of aardvarks, elephants and kin.

image:image.image:title: sengis

image:image.image:title: exhibit
image:image.image:caption: On to the special exhibit! A nice surprise to see naturalist superstar Jonathan Kingdon's scientific illustrations and nature-inspired artwork displayed here. I've added photos of ones I liked the most.

image:image.image:title: opossum-gatortummy
image:image.image:caption: Years ago, my team dissected an alligator (for Allen et al. 2010,2014 papers if you are keeping track) that had an opposum in its stomach, during winter when feeding wasn't supposed to be happening much. So that came up again this year; and hopefully it does not make anything come up from your stomach. But this is real anatomy in action.

image:image.image:title: mouse-GIF
image:image.image:caption: Speaking of mouse hindlimb simulations, I didn't blog about this related paper that we published earlier in 2018, but it's very relevant. And GIF-worthy!
DAWNDINOS got a nice new 3D printer and we're gradually printing up some archosaurs to show.
Smaller but better: Freezersaurus 3, part of a proud dynasty!

Freeezersaurus 2 has been mostly vacated now; and Freezersaurus 3 is in place, with the contents shifted-- and a mad rush in action to get rid of (boil down + varnish bones of) as many specimens as I can! I have way too many... of course, mostly elephant bits. Here are the last big bits left in Freezersaurus 2; we are intimidated to move them...
Oddly, but somehow appropriately, there are ?350 year old whale bones on display in the hall next door, with a mysterious history.

image:image.image:title: pelvis
image:image.image:caption: Strange bony plaque on the left pelvis (hip) region; something I'd never seen before in any elephant (and I've seen many). Why? The programme offers a reasonable explanation.

image:image.image:title: ankle
image:image.image:caption: The left ankle was in poor shape- degenerative joint disease aplenty. From giving rides? Injury? Being left chained up? All of these things and more?

image:image.image:title: hindfoot
image:image.image:caption: Surprisingly, Jumbo's feet were not in nasty condition in terms of pathologies. I'd expected to see that. They'd been painted and drilled for mounting, but were not riddled with arthritic changes that I could see.

image:image.image:title: elbow
image:image.image:caption: Right elbow with some pathologies consistent with degenerative joint disease.

image:image.image:title: forelimb
image:image.image:caption: Right forelimb, showing that the "growth plates" (epiphyses") were not all fused, consistent with Jumbo still growing-- as expected for an African male elephant in his 20's.

image:image.image:title: Model-fig

image:image.image:title: human-mouse
image:image.image:caption: Mouse and human legs in right side view, going through walking cycles in simulations.

image:image.image:title: excursions
image:image.image:caption: Muscle-by-muscle data; most mouse muscles go through smaller excursions; a few go through greater; some are the same as humans'.

image:image.image:title: activation-length
image:image.image:caption: Simulated stride for mouse and human; with muscles either almost inactive (Act=0.05) or fully active (Act=1). Red curve goes through much bigger excursions (along y-axis) than blue curve), so humans should use bigger % of their muscle fibre lengths in walking.

image:image.image:title: croc2

image:image.image:title: Ele_R_manus_B (61)
image:image.image:caption: Closeup of the glistening channels for the flexor tendons. They are lined with lubricative tissue to help the tendons glide through them. And the tendons do need to be able to glide- although elephant feet look very solid from the outside, and are to an extent, but we've done studies showing that they do move if you apply even a moderate load to them in a cadaver, and thus would move in life, too.

image:image.image:title: Ele_R_manus_B (60)
image:image.image:caption: Forefoot with flexor tendons removed, revealing the channels that they coursed through.

image:image.image:title: Ele_R_manus_B (62)
image:image.image:caption: Removed the digital flexor muscle so the three major tendons can be seen (the two short side branches to the first and fifth toes have been cut off).

image:image.image:title: Ele_R_manus_B (59)
image:image.image:caption: Tendons of the digital flexor muscle exposed.

image:image.image:title: Ele_R_manus_B (56)
image:image.image:caption: Palmar tendons and muscles; the common digital extensor muscle group. Clenches the toes. Not a small muscle, either!

image:image.image:title: Ele_R_manus_B (53)
image:image.image:caption: Elephant's-eye-view looking down onto the fat pad, where the palm of the foot in the image below would be placed in life.

image:image.image:title: Ele_R_manus_B (50)
image:image.image:caption: Fat pad removed, looking up through where it was at the palm of the "hands", where the tendons and ligaments connect to the five toes. Each arc-like structure is a toe; the "thumb" (first toe) is on the upper left.

image:image.image:title: Ele_R_manus_B (47)
image:image.image:caption: Skinned foot, oblique front/inside view again, as above.

image:image.image:title: Ele_R_manus_B (46)
image:image.image:caption: Looking down onto the inside of the toenails, toes 3 and 4. Healthy, relatively intact tissue; no swelling or bleeding or other pathology.

image:image.image:title: Ele_R_manus_B (44)
image:image.image:caption: Looking up at the palm. You can see the bulbous fat pad (yellower tissue) bulging out in the centre of the palm, and segments of it extending between each finger, separated by fibrous tracts. I love this anatomy. I can stare at it for hours and still be fascinated after all these years. So complex!

image:image.image:title: A (35)
image:image.image:caption: The curator cleared a space on a table for me to set bones on. Then the anatomizing and photographing began!

image:image.image:title: A (45)

image:image.image:title: A (18)
image:image.image:caption: Looking down at the top/ankle end of the tarsometatarsal (sole) bones in a hatchling ostrich: the three bones are separate and hollow, where "cartilage cones" would have filled them in.

image:image.image:title: B (141)
image:image.image:caption: Left side view of the pelvis of a very mature, HUGE Casuarius casuarius (cassowary). The space between the ilium (upper flat bone) and ischium (elongate bone on middle right side) has begun to be closed by a mineralization of the membrane that spanned those bones in life. A side effect of maturity, most likely. But cool- I've never seen this in a ratite bird before, that I can recall.

image:image.image:title: C (45)
image:image.image:caption: Ossified tendons (little spurs of long, thin bone) on the soles of the feet (tarsometatarsal bones) of a brush-turkey (Alectura lathami)- seldom described in this unusual galliform bird or its close relatives, and thus nice to see. These would be parts of the toe-flexor tendons.

image:image.image:title: B (160)
image:image.image:caption: Also very-unfused knee joints of a Darwin's rhea. Cool Y-shape!

image:image.image:title: B (79)
image:image.image:caption: Adult kiwi's tibiotarsi (sorry, blurry photo) in which all fusion is complete.

image:image.image:title: B (29)
image:image.image:caption: Juvenile kiwi's shank (tibiotarsus) bones viewed from the top (proximal) ends, showing the bubbly nubbins of bone (very bottom of each bone image) that are the "cranial tibial epiphyses" often mistaken for patellae.

image:image.image:title: ChadwickFig2-knee3D
image:image.image:caption: 3D model of an ostrich knee, showing: A, view looking down onto the top of the tibia (shank), with the major collateral ligaments (CL), and B, view looking straight at the front of the knee joint, with major organs of interest near the patella, sans muscles.

image:image.image:title: RegnaultFig7-cassowary
image:image.image:caption: Sectioning of a Southern Cassowary's knee extensor tendon, showing: A Similar section as in the emu image above. revealing similar regions and fibrous tissue (arrow), with no patella, just fat; and B, with collagen fibre bundles (col), fat cells (a), and cartilage-like tissue (open arrows) labelled.

image:image.image:title: RegnaultFig9-evolution
image:image.image:caption: Evolution of patellar form in birds. White branches indicate no patella, blue is a small flake of bone for a patella, green is something bigger, yellow is a double-patella in ostriches, and grey is uncertain. Note the uncertainty and convergent evolution of the patella in ratite birds, which is remarkable but fits well with their likely convergent evolution of flightlessness and running adaptations.

image:image.image:title: RegnaultFig2-emu
image:image.image:caption: Fatty knee extensor tendon of emus, lacking a patella. The fatty tissue is split into superficial (Sup) and deep regions, with a pad corresponding to the fat pad in other birds continuous with it and the knee joint meniscus (cushioning pad). The triceps femoris (knee extensor) muscle group inserts right into the fatty tendon, continuing over it. A is a schematic; B is a dissection.

image:image.image:title: LamasFig6data
image:image.image:caption: Data for an extra set of emus studied by coauthor Russ Main in the USA, which grew their muscles similarly to our UK group. The exponents (y-axis) show how much more strongly the muscles grown than isometry (maintaining the same relative size), which is the dotted line at 1.0.

image:image.image:title: giraffe right fore hooves
image:image.image:caption: Like rhinos, elephants and many other large mammals, giraffes (especially in captivity) are vulnerable to foot/hoof pathologies, such as this very skewed/divergent pair of nails. This can lead to them walking very abnormally, getting infections or arthritis and other problems, so it is very serious.

image:image.image:title: giraffe trachea diameter - 2
image:image.image:caption: Cross-section of trachea (windpipe). A narrow tube should give less dead space to move in/out with each breath, so it makes sense for such a huge, long-necked animal to have such a thin trachea.

image:image.image:title: giraffe jugular lumen and valves - 4
image:image.image:caption: The jugular vein, opened to show the valves, which prevent blood from flowing back down the neck.

image:image.image:title: A tiger salamander, Ambystoma

image:image.image:title: Elephant baby
image:image.image:caption: Breaking up the monotony of the text with a baby elephant we met during our research in Thailand (Chiang Mai, here). It was just a few days old and VERY cuddly and playful (chewing on everything!) but it's mother did not want us playing with it so we only gave a quick hello.

image:image.image:title: Tensor fasciae latae of an elephant
Cats, damn cats!
image:image.image:caption: If this post bummed you out, just focus on these contented cats.

image:image.image:title: penguin-glock
image:image.image:caption: This jaunty chap was staying put in his burrow while people walked by. We came closer and he kept rotating his head around, staring at us. I first took it as cute juvenile behaviour, but on later observations of penguins realized it was a threat- "My beak is sharp! Stay back, bro, or I'll glock ya!"

image:image.image:title: Penguins8to10
image:image.image:caption: Three wee little chicks.

image:image.image:title: Penguin6
image:image.image:caption: The fluffy baby shown in the photo above. Nice pose, and lots of anatomy shown. And check it out- gastroliths?!? In such a young animal-- is it even feeding yet?

image:image.image:title: Penguin7

image:image.image:title: Penguin5

image:image.image:title: Penguin4

image:image.image:title: Palaeospheniscus bones
image:image.image:caption: Part of the rather nice skeleton of Palaeospheniscus patagonicus, an Oligocene/Miocene largish penguin; from the MFN collections in Trelew, Argentina and collected nearby.

image:image.image:title: Palaeospheniscus TMT
image:image.image:caption: For me, the diagnostic trait of a penguin skeleton: the very short, tobust tarsometatarsus. From Palaeospheniscus, as above.

image:image.image:title: Vulture
image:image.image:caption: Ominous onlooker.

image:image.image:title: Cuban croc
image:image.image:caption: Cuban crocodile adult relaxing in a nearby enclosure. Pound-for-pound, a scary croc, but these acted like puppies with their trainers.

image:image.image:title: Siamese crocodile

image:image.image:title: Waiting croc

image:image.image:title: bantha-dissect2
image:image.image:caption: Jawa 37C-H4 sketching droid illustration: My dissection of a bantha, showing the tongue attachments (note the distal bifurcation), digestive tract and foot structure. The colour variations in the digestive tract seem to be produced by commensal arthroreptiles.

image:image.image:title: krayt-dissection2
image:image.image:caption: Jawa 37C-H4 sketching droid illustration: My dissection of the Greater Krayt Dragon, to extract the Dragon Pearl. The stormtrooper shown forgot the tale that Krayts take 1 hour to die, and so got too close too soon.

image:image.image:title: dewback-dissection2
image:image.image:caption: Jawa 37C-H4 sketching droid illustration: My dissection of a common dewback, showing the caudofemoral muscle and tendon, tail fat body, and fibrous pads used while resting on the sand.

image:image.image:title: krayt
image:image.image:caption: Two fragmentary skeletons of small Krayt Dragons, from the Corellian Science Museum. (Image source here)

image:image.image:title: Krayt_Dragon_by_jeddibub
image:image.image:caption: One of your Terran artists (jeddbub on deviantart) produced a provocative imagining of a Greater Krayt Dragon facing a Jedi. I'd wager for the former.

image:image.image:title: Stormtrooper_on_Dewback
image:image.image:caption: Stormtrooper on a Dewback in the Eastern Dune Sea (image source here).

image:image.image:title: Silceoderms
image:image.image:caption: Curious microstructure of the small "siliceoderms" from dewback skin that I have described-- single 'derm on the left, multiple 'derms surrounding a stomata on the right.

image:image.image:title: krayt-data
image:image.image:caption: Although based on little concrete data, my analysis of known Krayt and related specimens suggests that they change continuously during ontogeny, although leg number may shift more suddenly (I predict this happens during their first metamorphosis at sexual maturity). Strong allometric scaling of neck and total length is evident- if the two lengths scaled as mass^0.33 they would be maintaining shape across the proposed growth series. But they don't.

image:image.image:title: sw speed
image:image.image:caption: Maximal speed vs. body mass data from (black) Terran animals (source), and (green) Tatooine megafauna (plus non-native Kell dragons for comparison). As size increases past ~100 kg mass, speed inevitably declines.

image:image.image:title: GreaterKrayt-WOSW
image:image.image:caption: Another Terran artist renders a compelling illustration, of a Greater Krayt Dragon in life. Where indeed do they get their information from? Bothan spies, I suspect. (Source)

image:image.image:title: Mammoth pic
image:image.image:caption: This is the mammoth image I remember, from a 1971 book, with no artist credited. It's actually not as good as I remember, by modern standards at least.

image:image.image:title: mammoth-butt (2)
image:image.image:caption: Yep. That's what it looks like. Nope, not the front end. That orifice is not the mouth. This is the XXXXX mammoth.

In the end, from all that proboscidean diversity we were left with just 2 or 3 species (depending on your species concepts; it's probably worth calling the African forest elephant its own species, Loxodonta cyclotis). The exhibit closes with a consideration of their conservation and fate. Ironically, this elephant skull could not be mounted with its tusks on display, because that would be commercializing ivory usage-- even though the whole point of the exhibit's denouement is to explain why elephants need protection!

image:image.image:title: Mammoth skull
image:image.image:caption: Mammoth skull! A nice one, too.

image:image.image:title: Arctodus and Homotherium

image:image.image:caption: Lyuba and scientists studying her, which also shows how rigid the carcass is.

image:image.image:title: Pygmy mammoth teeth
image:image.image:caption: The world's smallest mammoth (left), molar tooth compared with that of its much larger ancestor Palaeoloxodon. The status of Mammuthus creticus as a dwarf mammoth from Crete was cemented by Victoria Herridge and colleagues, including Adrian Lister at the NHM.

image:image.image:title: Ass demons!
image:image.image:caption: The dance is over, thanks to ass demons. That's right, ass demons. Many Burmese were surely frightened or inspired by these terracota warriors from 1400s AD. These warriors represented king Mara's forces that attempted to disrupt the Buddha's meditation. As ass demons would tend to do. (I hate it when that happens)

image:image.image:title: Dancing Ganesha
image:image.image:caption: Statue of the Indian elephant diety Ganesha from ~750 AD. As the placard explains, Ganesha got his elephant's head when Shiva freaked out and cut off the human one, then promised to make amends by substituting the head of the next animal he saw.

image:image.image:title: Ox scapula

image:image.image:title: African fish masks

image:image.image:title: hippo-god-Egypt

image:image.image:title: RVC Anatomy Museum, Part 4- Birds and friends
hand
image:image.image:caption: Ostrich hand showing the three digits: 1st (top), 2nd (middle), and 3rd (hidden behind skin, but still with a hint of a claw). What are they used for? Probably not a lot.

image:image.image:title: action-shot-group
image:image.image:caption: Research Fellow Jeff Rankin, myself and technician/MRes student Kyle Chadwick get to work.

image:image.image:title: thorax-lung
image:image.image:caption: Internal view of the ribcage, showing (right side; bright red colour) where the rigid avian lung is tightly adhered to the dorsal side of the thorax.

image:image.image:title: thigh-pneumatic
image:image.image:caption: A curious region of the mid-thigh (caudal/posterior side), where two features are notable: (1) a ligamentous loop (called an ansa) from the femur that constrains the line of action of the big "hamstring" iliofibularis muscle (~mammalian biceps femoris), keeping the tendon close to the knee; and (2) a series of very complex sheets of epithelium that partition a series of air sacs extending down the thigh; these also invade the femur. Yes, to a sense, an ostrich has bellows in its thighs that might aid its breathing as it runs. This aspect o anatomy is almost totally unstudied!

image:image.image:title: stomach-gastroliths
image:image.image:caption: Gizzard/ventriculus, upper stomach/proventriculus (upper left), and stomach contents: grass and stomach stones (gastroliths).

image:image.image:title: ostrich-head-neck-Thing
image:image.image:caption: Skinned head, neck and thorax, exposing the trachea (windpipe) and esophagus (entry to gut; in my hand). There was an odd thickening in the esophagus here; we were not sure if this was injury or some sort of gland or muscular region.

image:image.image:title: lungs-sacs
image:image.image:caption: Looking into the thorax; heart (was on far left side of photo) and liver removed to expose the air sacs around the lungs, and the lungs just past their translucent membrane.

image:image.image:title: Jeff-leg
image:image.image:caption: Left leg, skinned and revealing the massive thigh and calf muscles, which can comprise >20% of an ostrich's weight per leg!

image:image.image:title: hand-feathers
image:image.image:caption: Outer view of the wing feathers attached to the hand; only the largest, thickest ones have been left unplucked. Note the puckered skin where feathers have been taken out of their follicles.

image:image.image:title: gutted carcass
image:image.image:caption: View of the left side of the ostrich, skinned and partly gutted. Shoulder closest; then ribcage and left leg.

image:image.image:title: Patrox
image:image.image:caption: Panthera atrox (large American lion) from the NHM in LA. Oh yes we'll be applying our insights to strange extinct cats, too!

image:image.image:title: jaguar
image:image.image:caption: Dodgy-looking bagged-up skinned jaguar (bag-uar?) after delivery from Scotland.

image:image.image:title: BagOCats1
image:image.image:caption: The Bag-o-Cats: whole specimens of a black-footed cat (Felis nigripes), juvenile cheetah, and juvenile snow leopard. I think. Sometimes you get a bag-o-cats and are not sure.

image:image.image:title: pig-bad-feet
image:image.image:caption: I know little about this case, posted on Reddit (link here), except that the overgrown, grossly deformed toes/hooves of this pig are like nothing I've seen before! This almost gave me nightmares. Poor chicken-footed pig!

image:image.image:title: bipedal-pig
image:image.image:caption:
Another crazy case; but this one I was able to track down more about after reading the Reddit post here. The Getty images page says:
This photo dated November 24, 2011 shows a Chinese farmer showing off his prize swine, which he named 'Strong Pig', as the disabled animal keeps its 30kgs of body suspended in midair, in Mengcheng, east China's Anhui province. The pig has become an internet sensation around China due to its ability to walk around balancing on its two front legs. TOPSHOTS CHINA OUT AFP PHOTO (Photo credit should read STR/AFP/Getty Images)

image:image.image:title: wonky hooves (3)

image:image.image:title: wonky hooves (1)
image:image.image:caption: Craaaaaaazy overgrown ?cow hooves, from the RVC's pathology collection.

image:image.image:title: Tragulus with long spint bone
image:image.image:caption: Tragulus, or mouse-deer, with freaky long "splint bones" (evolutionarily reduced sole bones or metatarsals) and dainty hooved feet. At Univ. Mus. Zoology- Cambridge.

image:image.image:title: ACPC18 White rhino foot health check
image:image.image:caption: Foot health check on a white rhino at a UK zoo. Photo by Ann & Steve Toon, http://www.toonphoto.com/

image:image.image:title: pig foot XROMM
image:image.image:caption: X-ray image from our 3D XROMM analyses of foot biomechanics, here showing a pig studied by Dr. Olga Panagiotopoulou. With data like these, we not only can measure how the tiny bones move, but also get better estimates of the loads on the soft tissues within those feet. Those loads should relate to the risks of musculoskeletal injury or disease.

image:image.image:title: paracerathere
image:image.image:caption: If we understand how foot form, function and pathology relate in diverse living hoofed mammals, we can start to piece together how extinct ones lived and evolved- like this giant rhinoceros! At IVPP museum in Beijing.

image:image.image:title: Moschus deer feet
image:image.image:caption: Moschus, Siberian musk deer with remarkable splayed hooves/claws; aiding it in crossing snowy or swampy ground. At Univ. Mus. Zoology- Cambridge.

image:image.image:title: giraffe hooves bad
image:image.image:caption: Overgrown giraffe hooves. An all-too-common problem, and one we're tacking with gusto lately, thanks to PhD student Chris Basu's NERC-funded giraffe project!

image:image.image:title: rhino-feet (7)
image:image.image:caption: Another osteomyelitis fracture, visible in a CT scan.

image:image.image:title: rhino-feet (6)
image:image.image:caption: Deep holes in some of the bones: infection, injury?

image:image.image:title: rhino-feet (5)
image:image.image:caption: Nasty osteoarthritis wearing away the bone at the joint surface. Most cases occurred in the most distal joint.

image:image.image:title: rhino-feet (1)
image:image.image:caption: Hidden treasures abound!

image:image.image:title: Archaeopteryx
image:image.image:caption: Archaeopteryx, the Berlin specimen. Helluva fossil, but nary a patella!

image:image.image:title: Elephant skull _Se1_Im002
image:image.image:caption: Elephant skull mystery x-ray

image:image.image:title: Siamese crocs
image:image.image:caption: Siamese crocodiles. They were apart when we entered, then got snuggly later, as I've often seen this species do.

image:image.image:title: Paleosuchus trigonatus
image:image.image:caption: Endearing shot of a crocodylian I seldom get to see anywhere: Paleosuchus trigonatus, the Cuvier's Dwarf Caiman. Spiny armoured hide and quite terrestrial; poorly known in many ways. Some more info is here- http://crocodilian.com/paleosuchus/description.html (note its tortured taxonomy)

image:image.image:title: Osteolaemus-babies
image:image.image:caption: And babies of said Osteolaemus!

image:image.image:title: Osteolaemus nesting
image:image.image:caption: Yes, that is a Dwarf African crocodile, Osteolaemus, and it is a female on her nest-mound. Which means...

image:image.image:title: Osteolaemus eggs
image:image.image:caption: Eggs of said Osteolaemus.

image:image.image:title: bloated fish
image:image.image:caption: The fish in question.

image:image.image:title: baboon in vampire bat pose
image:image.image:caption: The pose of this ?baboon? struck me as very peculiar, and menacing- reminiscent of a vampire bat's pose, to me.

image:image.image:title: anteaters
image:image.image:caption: Nice anteater skeleton and skin.

image:image.image:title: wombat
image:image.image:caption: Nice anteater skeleton and skin.

image:image.image:title: rhino-sans-horn
image:image.image:caption: Sad display of a stuffed rhino with the horn removed, and signage explaining the problem of thefts of those horns from museum specimens of rhinos worldwide.

image:image.image:title: bigass skate
image:image.image:caption: "That's one bigass skate," I murmured to myself.

image:image.image:title: bigass halibut
image:image.image:caption: "That's one bigass halibut," I quipped.

image:image.image:title: Tring-ungulate exhibit
image:image.image:caption: Bovids to the right of me, pinnipeds above, what's a guy to do but squee?

image:image.image:title: Osteology collection at Tring
image:image.image:caption: Inside the avian osteology collection at Tring. Sterlie at it might seem, places like this are fertile breeding grounds for scientific discovery.

image:image.image:title: Darwins-chickens (10)
image:image.image:caption: XXXX breed in right side view, with the patella indicated by a red arrow. It is still attached to the tibiotarsus by the patellar tendon (often misnamed the patellar "ligament", but it is just a continuation of the proximal tendon).

image:image.image:title: Darwins-chickens (11)
image:image.image:caption: The hindlimb of a Polish Silver Laced breed, nicely showing the ossified tendons (red arrow) along the tarsometatarsus. Why these tendons turn into bone is one of the great unsolved mysteries of bone biology/mechanics and avian evolution. Check out the famed feather crest here.

image:image.image:title: Darwin and the chicken postdocs
image:image.image:caption: Dr Heather Paxton and Dr Jeffrey Rankin, postdoc researchers working on our collaborative BBSRC chicken biomechanics grant (see thechickenofthefuture.com), explain their science to an attentive Darwin.

image:image.image:title: Darwins-chickens (14)
image:image.image:caption: Darwin's handwritten label and the well-endowed patella of the Spanish Cock. What? Oh, you. Stop it.

image:image.image:title: Darwins-chickens (13)
image:image.image:caption: Hindlimb of a Malay breed of chicken, which Wikipedia nicely tells the story of its misnomer (it may originate from Pakistan, not Malaysia!). Can you find the nice patella? Check out Darwin's lovely label, too.

image:image.image:title: Darwins-chickens (12)
image:image.image:caption: Darwin's example of a wild-type chicken; a Red Junglefowl. As he suspected, these Asian birds were the ancestors of domestic chickens, but today evidence suggests that domestication occurred multiple times in Asia and with different wild varieties of junglefowl bred/mixed in different regions.

image:image.image:title: Darwins-chickens (9)
image:image.image:caption: A Golden Pencil Hamburgh breed of chicken (cockerel), whose skeleton features the leg and a fine articulated patella.
